title: ISIS appoint new leader after al-Baghdadi killed in US raid in northern Syria

ISIS have appointed a new leader after Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi was killed in a daring US raid in northern Syria, according to reports.

Baghdadi's successor is said to be Abdullah Qardash, also known as Hajji Abdullah al-Afari.

He was chosen by Baghdadi in August to run the group's "Muslim affairs," according to ISIS' official Amaq news outlet.

And American outlet Newsweek reports he is now set to succeed Baghdadi as leader of the terror death cult.

Little is known about him but he once served under Saddam Hussein in Iraq.

(Image: AFP via Getty Images)

He takes over ISIS at a time where the cult has little or no held territory but remains capable of inspiring horrific 'lone wolf' attacks across the world.

Baghdadi, who died after detonating a suicide vest following a Delta Team operation, built ISIS' self-styled caliphate out of al-Qaeda's Iraqi branch.

But a regional intelligence official reportedly told Newsweek that the influential hard-line cleric's role had become largely symbolic.

"Baghdadi was a figurehead. He was not involved in operations or day-to-day," the official told Newsweek.

"All Baghdadi did was say yes or no - no planning."

Baghdadi was born in the central Iraqi city of Samarra in 1971 and named Ibrahim Awad Ibrahim al-Badr.

(Image: REUTERS)

(Image: AL-FURQAN MEDIA/AFP via Getty Im)

In spite of being a weakly child he enjoyed a successful military career and rose to command al-Qaeda’s Iraqi division which eventually broke away to form ISIS.

It is believed he was a cleric in a mosque in Samarra the city around the time of the US-led invasion in 2003.

It is thought he was already a jihadist during the rule of former Iraqi leader Saddam Hussein.

Others suggest he was radicalised during the time he was held at Camp Bucca, a US facility in southern Iraq where many al-Qaeda commanders were detained.

He was declared a terrorist by the USA as far back as 2011 but truly came to prominence in 2014 when ISIS had captured vast swathes of territory in Iraq and Syria.

(Image: AFP/Getty Images)

He soon became the known leader of ISIS after he delivered a rare televised sermon from a mosque in the captured Iraqi city of Mosul shortly after.

Appearing unmasked for the first time, he declared himself to be the caliph which is the political and religious leader of the global Muslim community.

He has been seen in pubic on just one other occasion, in an 18-minute video released in April this year.
